title: Victoria Memorial
summary: The Victoria Memorial is a grand marble monument situated in Central Kolkata, India, constructed by the British Raj between 1906 and 1921. It was dedicated to Queen Victoria, who served as Empress of India from 1876 to 1901. Standing as the world's largest monument to a monarch, it encompasses 26 hectares of gardens. The memorial prominently features Indo-Saracenic architecture and was initially conceived by Viceroy Lord Curzon to monumentalize the empire and foster loyalist sentiments. Today, it functions as a prominent museum under the Ministry of Culture, Government of India, and remains a major tourist attraction in the city.

Exhibits prominent features of Indo-Saracenic architecture.
Functions as a museum under the control of the Ministry of Culture, Government of India.
Planning for the memorial was initiated by Viceroy Lord Curzon before Victoria's death in 1901 to monumentalize the empire.
timeline: January 22, 1901: Queen Victoria dies, providing the 'appropriate occasion' for the memorial.
January 24, 1901: Lord Curzon writes to Lord George Hamilton proposing the construction of a grand building with a museum and gardens.
February 26, 1901: Lord Curzon publicly addresses the Asiatic Society, detailing his vision for the stately memorial.
1906: Construction of the Victoria Memorial officially begins.
1921: The construction of the Victoria Memorial is completed and it opens to the public.

current_status: The Victoria Memorial is currently a large marble monument and a functional museum, under the control of the Ministry of Culture, Government of India. It encompasses 26 hectares of gardens and continues to be one of the most popular attractions in Kolkata.
future_prospects: Continued preservation and maintenance as a national heritage site.
Potential for further development of its museum collections and exhibitions.
Ongoing role as a key educational and cultural institution for future generations.
